title: About
text:
I’m a data analyst at the Congressional Policy and Budget Research Department of the Philippine House of Representatives.
My work involves analyzing economic data, creating visualizations, and producing reports that help inform policy decisions.

title: Welcome
text:
Data analyst at the Congressional Policy and Budget Research Department, Philippine House of Representatives.
I focus on economic analysis and data visualization, making complex policy topics accessible through interactive visualizations and analytical reports.



Economic policy analysis
Data visualization
Interactive dashboards
Research reports


Explore my projects or read my shorts for quick insights.

title: Quarto Website Setup Guide for GitHub Pages
text:
This guide documents how to create and publish a Quarto website on GitHub Pages.



Quarto installed (download here)
Git installed
GitHub account





Go to GitHub and create a new repository
Name it <username>.github.io (e.g., edreiyu.github.io)
Initialize it (with or without README)
Clone the repository to your local machine:
git clone https://github.com/<username>/<username>.github.io.git
cd <username>.github.io






project:
  type: website
  output-dir: docs

website:
  title: "Your Website Title"
  navbar:
    left:
      - href: index.qmd
        text: Home
      - about.qmd

format:
  html:
    theme:
      - cosmo
      - brand
    css: styles.css
    toc: true
Key configuration: - output-dir: docs - GitHub Pages will serve from this folder - type: website - Tells Quarto this is a website project



---
title: "Your Website Title"
---

# Welcome to My Website

This is the home page content.

## About This Site

Add your content here using Markdown.



---
title: "About"
---

## About Me

Add information about yourself here.



/* Add custom CSS here */




Create an empty .nojekyll file in the root directory:
touch .nojekyll
Why? This tells GitHub Pages not to process your site with Jekyll, which is important for Quarto sites.



Run Quarto to render your website:
quarto render
This will create all HTML files in the docs/ directory.



git add .
git commit -m "Initial Quarto website setup"
git push origin main




Go to your repository on GitHub
Click Settings → Pages (in the left sidebar)
Under Source, select:

Branch: main
Folder: /docs

Click Save




After a few minutes, your website will be available at:
https://<username>.github.io



Whenever you want to update your website:

Edit your .qmd files
Run quarto render to rebuild
Commit and push changes:
git add .
git commit -m "Update content"
git push origin main





Preview locally: Run quarto preview to see changes before publishing
Add pages: Create new .qmd files and add them to _quarto.yml navbar
Themes: Explore other Quarto themes
Advanced features: Add blog posts, custom layouts, and more using Quarto documentation







Make sure you ran quarto render before pushing
Check GitHub Actions tab for build errors
Clear browser cache





Verify GitHub Pages is set to serve from /docs folder
Ensure .nojekyll file exists
Check that docs/ folder is committed to git





Check that site_libs/ folder is in docs/ directory
Verify all files in docs/ are committed





your-repo/
├── .nojekyll           # Prevents Jekyll processing
├── _quarto.yml         # Main configuration
├── index.qmd           # Home page
├── about.qmd           # About page
├── styles.css          # Custom CSS
└── docs/               # Generated HTML (published to GitHub Pages)
    ├── .nojekyll
    ├── index.html
    ├── about.html
    ├── site_libs/
    └── ...




Quarto Websites
GitHub Pages Documentation
Quarto Publishing Guide
